I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB), through the proposed knowledge and support 
technical assistance (TA), will establish and implement the Article 6 Support Facility (“the support 
facility”).1 Through the support facility, ADB will provide capacity building, and technical and policy 
development support to developing member countries (DMCs) to help them to identify, develop, 
and pilot mitigation actions under the framework of Article 6 of the Paris Agreement. 
 
2.  The TA is included in the 2018-2019 Work Plan of the Climate Change and Disaster Risk 
Management Thematic Group approved by Management.2 It supports the operational priorities of 
ADB’s Strategy 2030: tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and 
enhancing environmental sustainability.3 The TA is also aligned with ADB’s Climate Change 
Operational Framework 2017–2030,4 which strengthens ADB support to DMCs in meeting their 
commitments under the Paris Agreement, including nationally determined contributions (NDCs).5 
 
3.  The support facility will be part of ADB’s Carbon Market Program (CMP).6 Established in 
2006,  the  CMP  provides  technical  support  and  carbon  finance  to  greenhouse  gas  (GHG) 
mitigation projects in DMCs, including supporting DMCs to use market-based approaches as part 
of achieving their NDCs.7 It aims to build on the assistance provided to date, while responding to 
the  ongoing  negotiations  and  developments  regarding  the  operationalization  of  the  Paris 
Agreement. ADB designed the TA on the strength of its carbon market institutional expertise and 
lessons learned through the CMP. The TA will allow ADB to continue to play a leadership role in 
the development of post-2020 carbon markets.   
 
4.  ADB has developed the TA in consultation with The Government of Germany through The 
Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, and Nuclear Safety of Germany, and 
the Swedish Energy Agency. The design of the TA has been informed by both countries’ programs 
for supporting pilot mitigation actions under the framework of Article 6. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
  
5.  The Paris Agreement sets out the long-term goals for all countries8 to limit the global 
temperature increase to well below 2oC, while pursuing a 1.5oC target. It requires all countries to 
contribute  through  their  NDCs,  which  set  out  their  national  post-2020  climate  targets  and 
commitments.  As  of  August  2018,  174 parties,  including  most  of  ADB’s  DMCs,  have 
communicated their first NDCs. However, the collective ambitions are not sufficient to meet the

based approaches. Mitigation actions in this report refer to cooperative approaches under Article 6.2 and the new 
mechanism under Article 6.4.

Paris Agreement goals, and efforts are needed by all countries to raise ambitions.9 
 
6.  Article  6  of  the  Paris  Agreement  enables  countries  to  cooperate  voluntarily  in 
implementing their NDCs through market and nonmarket-based approaches. Article 6 could help 
countries access cost-effective mitigation opportunities and additional climate finance streams 
through cooperation, and form the basis for raising their ambitions over time. The market-based 
approaches in Article 6 include cooperative approaches under Article 6.2 and a new mitigation 
and sustainable development mechanism under Article 6.4.10 These lay the foundation for post-
2020 carbon markets under the Paris Agreement by allowing countries to use mitigation outcomes 
from another country toward their NDCs.  
 
7.  DMCs are developing and implementing national climate plans and policies to support 
NDC implementation. Almost all DMCs have provided commitments in their NDCs that are 
conditional (fully or partially) on international support. Cooperation under Article 6 could provide 
part of this support. Many DMCs have expressed their willingness to use market approaches as 
a key tool for NDC implementation and are working to understand how to engage under Article 6. 
For example, Pakistan and Thailand have indicated that they will consider the use of international 
cooperation, and India and Viet Nam have indicated that they will use market mechanisms to 
achieve their NDCs. The Republic of Korea states that it will partly use international market 
mechanisms to achieve its 2030 mitigation target, while Bangladesh does not rule out the use of 
market-based mechanisms.11 
 
8.  To  engage  under  Article  6,  DMCs  must  understand  the  specific  requirements  and 
associated accounting systems that they will need to manage participation. The Paris Agreement 
requires countries that engage under Article 6 to promote sustainable development and ensure 
environmental integrity, transparency, and robust accounting. DMCs need to understand what 
this means in practice. The rules for the implementation of Article 6 are expected to be adopted 
at the 24th session of the Conference of the Parties 24 in December 2018. However, the 
negotiations and elaboration of many issues are likely to continue well beyond 2018, creating 
challenges for DMCs. 
 
9.  The DMCs have growing momentum to undertake pilot activities under Article 6.12 Pilot 
activities will play a critical role in building the capacity of DMCs to assess the use of cooperative 
approaches and the new 6.4 mechanism; contribute practical insights on how mitigation actions 
can be designed and implemented, including encouraging innovation, upscaled action, policy 
reform, and the use of climate-friendly technologies; help DMCs begin to develop the institutional 
capacity and systems needed; and help DMCs begin to engage the private sector in mitigation 
actions under Article 6. Pilot activities could also demonstrate how Article 6 could support 
activities outside the scope of an NDC, with a view to incorporating the activities in the conditional 
part of the NDC over time. The lessons from pilot activities will strengthen DMCs’ ability as 
important stakeholders in the negotiations on the implementation of the Paris Agreement.  
 
10.  International market-based cooperation is crucial for promoting the cost-effectiveness and 
flexibility of mitigation action, and pilot activities undertaken by DMCs will highlight potential future

will only achieve one-third of the emission reductions necessary by 2030 to meet the Paris Agreement goals.

opportunities under Article 6 for ADB. The development of carbon markets under Article 6 is 
expected to lead to an inflow of carbon finance to Asia and the Pacific, stimulating mitigation 
activities and incentivizing the application of low-carbon technologies and the development of 
technical expertise to DMCs. This will likely lead to further opportunities for ADB to support 
upscaled mitigation actions in sectors such as low-carbon transport, renewable energy, and 
energy efficiency. The development of post-2020 carbon markets will also help ADB meet its 
operational targets by generating demand for low-carbon, climate-friendly projects and enhancing 
the internal rate of return for such projects. It will also present opportunities for ADB to cooperate 
with its international development partners in providing carbon finance and other cofinancing 
support enabling knowledge support for green growth in the region. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: low-carbon development in Asia and the 
Pacific accelerated (footnote 3). The TA will have the following outcome: Article 6 Support Facility 
operationalized.13 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
12.  ADB proposes to establish the Article 6 Support Facility under the CMP. Through the 
support facility, ADB will provide capacity building, and technical and policy development support 
to DMCs to help them to identify, develop, and pilot mitigation actions including activities related 
to cooperative approaches involving international transfers of mitigation outcomes in the context 
of Article 6.2 and under the new mechanism under Article 6.4.14 ADB will encourage innovation 
in the development of mitigation actions in DMCs, contribute to achieving a critical mass of 
expertise  on  Article  6,  draw  lessons  learned  from  pilot  activities,  and  enhance  DMCs’ 
preparedness for participation in post-2020 markets as well as their ability to contribute to 
international negotiations.   
 
13.  The TA team will work with ADB operations departments to build knowledge and capacity 
for mitigation actions under Article 6, and encourage consideration of Article 6 in ADB’s financing 
operations to enhance the opportunities for DMCs. The TA team will also coordinate with and 
maximize the synergies with ADB’s other initiatives and programs. 
 
14.  Output  1:  Capacity  of  developing  member  countries  to  identify  and  assess 
mitigation actions under Article 6 enhanced. This output entails providing support to DMCs to 
understand the opportunities and identify options for using cooperative approaches involving 
international transfers of mitigation outcomes and the new mechanism under Article 6 in achieving 
and enhancing their current and future NDCs. This includes supporting DMCs to consider 
activities beyond the scope of their current NDCs with a view to incorporating the activities in the 
conditional part of the NDCs. The TA will provide capacity building, and technical and policy 
development support to DMC governments, and undertake capacity development activities (such 
as workshops and publication of knowledge products) on key topics such as: identifying and 
designing policy measures (e.g., carbon pricing, where international cooperation can scale up 
and/or accelerate mitigation actions); developing appropriate institutional structures to manage 
                                                
13 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
14 This will support DMCs to use carbon markets and climate finance under the framework of Article 6 towards reaching 
national climate targets in their NDCs and to consider raising ambition.

4 
participation under Article 6; facilitating private and public sector involvement in mitigation actions; 
operationalizing environmental integrity in mitigation actions; designing and executing mitigation 
actions  for  generating  internationally  transferable  mitigation  outcomes  under  Article  6;  and 
integrating sustainable development benefits into mitigation actions.15 ADB will assist at least two 
DMCs under output 1. Consultations with DMCs on the scope of support are ongoing (footnote 
12). 
 
15.  Output 2: Capacity of developing member countries to pilot mitigation actions 
under Article 6 enhanced. This output involves the following activities:  
 
(i)  The TA team will support DMCs to identify and evaluate options for pilot mitigation 
actions under Article 6.2 and 6.4, considering: the DMC’s national climate plans 
and policies; the scope of their current NDC; environmental integrity; transparency; 
the mitigation action implementation timeline; the potential scale and type of 
emission reductions; potential transaction models for the mitigation outcomes; and 
the potential contribution of the mitigation action to sustainable development in the 
national context, including through the delivery of co-benefits. The TA team will 
consult  with  ADB  operations  departments  and  support  DMCs  to  target  pilot 
activities  in  sectors  with  high  potential  for  demonstrative  effect  and 
transformational change such as the energy and sustainable urban development 
sectors.16  
(ii)  The TA team will provide technical support to the activity implementers to pilot 
mitigation actions to: define the scope of the mitigation actions; develop and 
implement baseline and monitoring, reporting, and verification methodologies; and 
undertake necessary steps, to the extent possible, to qualify under Article 6. ADB 
will assist at least three pilot mitigation actions under output 2.17 
 
16.  Output 3: Capacity of developing member countries to undertake robust accounting 
and reporting of mitigation outcomes strengthened. Under this output, the TA team will work 
with DMCs to strengthen their capacity, systems, and infrastructure for: robust accounting of 
mitigation outcomes; ensuring environmental integrity; and reporting on the issuance, transfer, 
and retirement of mitigation outcomes. This includes monitoring, reporting, and verification of 
mitigation actions and corresponding adjustments as required under the Article 6 provisions in 
the Paris Agreement Rulebook. ADB will assist at least two DMCs under output 3. Consultations 
with DMCs regarding the scope of support are ongoing (footnote 12). 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $4,000,000, of which (i) $1,500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources); (ii) $1,500,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by The Government of Germany through The Federal Ministry for the 
Environment, Nature Conservation, and Nuclear Safety of Germany and administered by ADB; 
and (iii) $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Swedish Energy Agency and 
administered by ADB.18 The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
                                                
15 The United Nations 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development (2030 Agenda) and its 17 Sustainable Development 
Goals and the Paris Agreement are viewed as complementary mutually reinforcing instruments. The support facility 
will support DMCs to integrate the Sustainable Development Goals into Article 6 activities. 
16 The TA team will review projects and programs that are being considered for financing by the ADB.  
17 Consultations with ADB operational departments in regard to identifying potential mitigation activities are ongoing. 
18 Discussions with both donors on their respective cofinancing agreements are currently underway.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB, through the Climate Change and Disaster Risk Management Division under ADB’s 
Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department, will administer the TA. The Climate 
Change and Disaster Risk Management Division will work with ADB operations departments on 
the selection of DMCs and pilot mitigation activities. ADB will recruit individual international and/or 
national  consultants  through  framework  agreements,  as  required.  ADB  will  engage  the 
consultants and carry out procurement following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.

19.  Consulting services. ADB will recruit individual consultants to provide international and 
national consulting inputs. An estimated 84 person-months of international consulting inputs 
(carbon market expert, project manager [mitigation actions], GHG accounting expert) and 190 
person-months of national consulting inputs (carbon market expert, technical expert [mitigation 
actions], GHG accounting expert, research assistant, TA coordinator, and administrative assistant) 
are required to carry out activities under the TA. ADB will engage the consultants following the 
ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions.19  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $1,500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by The Government of Germany 
through The Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, and Nuclear Safety of 
Germany, (ii) ADB administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent 
of $1,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Swedish Energy Agency, and (iii) ADB 
providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis for Establishing 
a Support Facility for Article 6 of the Paris Agreement, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
